abstract.para: This guide describes how to attach a &productname; subscription to &rhel; 7 or CentOS Linux 7 using &suse;'s &smtool;.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: &productname; is a technology and support solution for mixed Linux environments. With a &productname; subscription, you can register and receive updates for &rhel;, CentOS Linux, and &sles;. An optional &ha; extension is also available.

To register &rhla; 7 or CentOS Linux 7, use &suse;'s &smtool; (⪪) for &sle; 12. ⪪ is a proxy system for the &scc;. The ⪪ server is registered with the &scc;, and other systems in the network are registered with the ⪪ server and receive packages from it directly. For more information, see the &smtool; Guide.

important.para: The &rmtool; (&rmt;) for &sle; 15 does not support &rhla;/CentOS 7 registration.

section.para: Registering &rhla; or CentOS Linux with ⪪ involves the following steps:

listitem.para: . Make sure you have everything required for the following procedures.
. This server must be installed on &sles; 12. You can skip this step if you already have an ⪪ server in your network.
. You can skip this step if &productname; is already enabled and mirrored on your ⪪ server.

note.title: &productname; and &sles; with Expanded Support
note.para: &productname; now provides what used to be covered by the &sles; with Expanded Support subscription. Some components might still use the Expanded Support name during the transition period.

listitem.para: The systems you want to register have been updated to the latest version of &rhla; 7 or CentOS Linux 7.

&sles; (&slsa;) 12 is installed and running in the same network as the systems you want to register. You can use the &productname; subscription to register the &slsa; server. To install the latest version of &slsa; 12, see the
&instquick;.
The &slsa; server has enough storage available for repository mirroring.

Downloaded packages are stored in /srv/www/htdocs/repo. The amount of storage required depends on the number of repositories that you mirror, and the number of products that you enable. We recommend 1.5 times the total size of all enabled repositories, or approximately 200 GB per release.
listitem.remark: This might not be enough! 200 GB was more than enough for RES8 during my test, but is not enough for my RES7 test. Over time, it might also become too small for RES8 as it gets more packages added to it.

listitem.para: If some packages could not be downloaded due to timeouts, rerun the smt-mirror command until all packages are downloaded.

The repodata directory on the ⪪ server will not be available until all of the packages for that repository are downloaded. If some packages could not be downloaded to the ⪪ server due to timeouts during the first mirroring, rerun the smt-mirror command until all packages are downloaded.
